IPF Weight Calibration for PNADC Data

Source: R/calibrate-ipf-weights.R
pnadc_ipf_calibrate.Rd

Usage

pnadc_ipf_calibrate(
  data,
  weight_var = "V1028",
  calibration_unit = "month",
  margins = c("age_group", "gender", "hh_group", "posest"),
  target_totals = NULL,
  bounds = c(0.1, 10),
  max_iter = 300L,
  tol = 1e-06,
  bias_correction = c("none", "propensity"),
  method = c("margin", "cell"),
  min_cell_size = 30L,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

data

A data.table with period assignments from pnadc_apply_periods() or pnadc_identify_periods(). Must contain the reference period columns (e.g., ref_month_yyyymm) and demographic variables.

weight_var

Character. Name of the original weight column, either "V1028" (quarterly) or "V1032" (annual). Default: "V1028".

calibration_unit

Character. Time unit for calibration: "month", "fortnight", or "week". Default: "month".

margins

Character vector of margin names to use. Available margins: "age_group" (9 age categories), "gender" (male/female), "hh_group" (household size: 1, 2, 3-4, 5+), "posest" (IBGE post-stratum), "rural_urban" (requires V1022). Default: c("age_group", "gender", "hh_group", "posest"). Use fewer/simpler margins for sparse data (fortnight, week).

target_totals

Optional data.table with external population totals from fetch_monthly_population(). If provided, final weights are scaled to match these totals. If NULL, weights preserve the sample's weighted totals.

bounds

Numeric vector of length 2. Weight adjustment bounds as ratios of the original weight, e.g., c(0.1, 10) allows weights to be reduced to 10\

max_iterInteger. Maximum number of IPF iterations. Default: 300.

tolNumeric. Convergence tolerance - iteration stops when the maximum relative change in weights is below this value. Default: 1e-6.

bias_correctionCharacter. Method for correcting selection bias in the determined sample. Options: "none" (default, use standard weights), "propensity" (use inverse probability weighting based on propensity scores for being in the determined sample).

methodCharacter. IPF method to use. Options: "margin" (default, iterate over independent margins), "cell" (iterate over hierarchical cells like nested raking, preserving anchor-period structure).

min_cell_sizeInteger. Minimum cell size threshold for adaptive margin collapsing. If any margin has cells smaller than this, the margin categories will be collapsed (e.g., 9 age groups -> 4). Default: 30. Set to 0 to disable.

verboseLogical. Print progress messages. Default: TRUE.

The input data.table with a new weight column added: weight_ipf_monthly, weight_ipf_fortnightly, or weight_ipf_weekly, depending on calibration_unit. Alternative weight calibration using Iterative Proportional Fitting (IPF). Unlike the nested-cells raking in pnadc_apply_periods(), this function adjusts weights to simultaneously match multiple independent margins: age groups, gender, household size, posest, and optionally rural/urban. The IPF algorithm iteratively adjusts weights to match target proportions for each margin. Critically, target proportions are derived from the FULL quarterly sample (all observations, not just those with determined reference periods). This corrects for selection bias in the month/fortnight/week determined sample.The algorithm flow:

  1. Create margin variables on ALL observations

  2. (Optional) Compute propensity scores and IPW for bias correction

  3. Calculate target proportions from FULL quarterly sample (unbiased)

  4. (Optional) Adaptively collapse sparse margins

  5. Filter to determined observations only

  6. Run IPF iterations (margin-based or cell-based)

  7. Apply weight bounds

  8. Scale to SIDRA population totals (each period to its containing month)

Available margins: age_group (9 categories from V2009), gender (V2007), hh_group (household size: 1, 2, 3-4, 5+), posest (IBGE post-stratum), rural_urban (V1022, if available).For sparse data (fortnight/week), use fewer margins to ensure convergence. Bias CorrectionThe bias_correction = "propensity" option models the probability of an observation being in the determined sample using logistic regression with age group, gender, posest (post-stratum), household size group, and rural/urban as predictors. Inverse probability weights (IPW) are then used as initial weights for IPF, directly addressing selection bias.

Cell-Based IPFThe method = "cell" option runs IPF within hierarchical cells (similar to nested raking) rather than matching independent margins. This preserves anchor-period totals within cells and often produces better temporal consistency.

Adaptive MarginsWhen min_cell_size > 0, margins with sparse cells are automatically collapsed to prevent extreme weight adjustments. For example, 9 age groups may be collapsed to 4 broader categories for fortnight/week calibration.
